Reconstructing Human Evolution: Achievements, Challenges, and Opportunities

It has to be noted that findings about the spread of a genetic variant that allows human adults to digest lactose generated expectations about a relatively high speed of ongoing genetic evolution in humankind. This variant appeared only 10,000 years ago, became widespread in many parts of the world in five to ten thousand years, and is still expanding; cf
Genes, Culture, and Human Evolution: A Synthesis

Yet recent measures of genetic variation worldwide suggest that such rapid adaptation is an exception, and genetic evolution, normally speaking, takes place at a much slower pace, beneficial variants needing several tens of thousands of years to become widespread
